item.title: A Nice Idea
item.dc:creator: Feather Tin
item.description:
Yet another article warning about the abuse of facial-recognition technology. And from a respected academic.

Yes, this a nice idea. And yes, \(\iota\) suppose it is necessary to encode regulations in law. But will the academics and law-makers ever realize that all their laws and regulations will not stop the problem? Do they not realize that government security agencies will ignore the law? Are they so naive as to assume that capitalist businesses will respect regulations?

This djinni is well and truly out of the bottle. Thermodynamics has a few words to say about reversing such things. \(\iota\) shouldn't need to elaborate further …

Our challenge is to figure out to deal with the reality facing us now and into the future.

item.title: In the Trenches with Ethereum
item.dc:creator: Feather Tin
item.description:
\(\iota\) have not fallen off the earth … or been picked up by the black helicopters. A call to arms is exciting: the first rush of emotion, the excitement of new ideas, the sheer challenges of communication and motivation. But battles are won and lost in the trenches and trenches are generally not pleasant places. So be it. \(\iota\) am in the trenches studying.

The Ethereum yellow paper is not the sort of thing to read with a beer in your hand and your feet up. It takes a little more concentration than that. Early stages yet, too early, in fact, to know if it will be useful. It is, at least, interesting.

item.title: On Suicide, Blister Packs, and Radicalization
item.dc:creator: Feather Tin
item.description:
A friend sent me a link to an article repeating the too oft told story of a somewhat directionless single white male turning to a popular video streaming service and getting sucked down an alt-right rabbit hole. This particular individual realized what had happened, changed political agendas, and is participating in a left-leaning counter action. \(\iota\) do not wish to discuss politics either way but instead want to make an observation about medical packaging.

item.title: So Much To Learn
item.dc:creator: Feather Tin
item.description:
So much to learn! Tor, IPFS, I2P, Tribler …

These approaches and software packages, even the ones that have failed to catch on in the past, may be worth rethinking since so-called "serverless computing" has become a thing. Yes, it is in the cloud, but it is transient. Can we make the vulnerable parts of some of these systems transient and thereby lessen their vulnerability?

So much to learn. So much to ponder.

item.title: On Building Consensus
item.dc:creator: Feather Tin
item.description:
To effect change we must work together. Reform is thwarted if we fail to come together in sufficient number or fail to stay united for sufficient time. Those looking to maintain the status quo know this and use fear, uncertainty, and doubt to sow disunity and exaggerate differences leading to the ineffective polarization seen so widely these days.

What can we do?

item.title: Hopeful News
item.dc:creator: Feather Tin
item.description:
This is the most hopeful news \(\iota\) have seen. CNBC reports Facebbok's job offer acceptance rate is plummeting:

<https://www.cnbc.com/2019/05/16/facebook-has-struggled-to-recruit-since-cambridge-analytica-scandal.html>

We (programmers, geeks, techies … call us what you will) may be slow to anger, slow to indignation. We take a long time to make up our minds. But you know what? That is because it takes time to reach truth. But once we find it, we stick to it.

Let's see how all those "thought leaders" and "visionaries" get on pounding their own code at scale.

item.title: On Data Security
item.dc:creator: Feather Tin
item.description:
As an IT professional \(\iota\) feel obliged to clear up a matter oft overlooked in today's media, both within our community and beyond. That is the matter of data security. While sceptical of absolutes \(\iota\) have studied enough mathematics to recognize such a rarity when one appears:

There is no such thing as secure data.

Perhaps that can be re-worded to be more easily remembered:

THERE IS NO SUCH THING AS SECURE DATA!!!

Every day it seems there are reports of newer and larger data breaches. Customer data, government data, health data. On and on without end. One would think that by now people would realize that there simply is no way to secure data.

"Secure data" is an oxymoron. You have a birthday, as does every person on the planet. That is a fact. You know it. \(\iota\) do not. Now record that fact and it becomes data. The defining characteristic of data is that it can be recalled. Write it on a piece of paper and someone can read it. Record it and someone can play it back.

If a fact can not be recovered it is not data. Relational database management systems exist to facilitate data recall. SQL searches, indexing, back-up and redundancy. These all exist to let people recover stored facts, to manage data.

Within information technology we discuss and debate techniques aimed at securing database systems. Reading such works, \(\iota\) can not help thinking of medieval architects designing ever larger and elaborate keeps, castles, and walled towns. Despite all their technological advances, it is well known that when such fortifications fell, it was most often not by force but through human action, accidental or treasonous. All modern database systems incorporate the same vulnerability. They are designed to allow the data to be recalled and read and processed.

And once recalled? That data can leak. Why do we act so surprised?
